title: Poverty rate for female-headed U.S. families falls in 2018 to lowest level on record
text:
Lions Gate/Courtesy Everett Collection A strong labor market is offering more job opportunities and higher pay to single moms.

The poverty rate of people living in female-headed households fell in 2018 to the lowest level on record, thanks to a strong labor market offering more job opportunities for black and Hispanic women.

Last year the poverty rate in female-led households dropped 1.7 percentage points to 26.8%, the U.S. Census Bureau said Tuesday. That’s the lowest level since the government began keeping track in 1959, topping the previous low set in 2000. (Figures are adjusted for historical purposes.)

Female-headed households were the only major kind of family to experience a significant decline in poverty in 2018, the Census said. They represent about 18% of the American population that lives in families for a total of nearly 47 million.

The improved financial well-being of female-headed families also lifted some 649,000 children above the poverty line last year, the agency said.

These families benefited from the strongest labor market in decades. Job openings hit a record high earlier this year, the unemployment rate fell to a 50-year low and wages rose at the fastest pace in a decade.

“More people from female-householder families found full-time, full-year employment in 2018 than in 2017, particularly among blacks and Hispanics. This led to higher incomes and fewer adults and children in poverty for these groups,” Census researchers John Creamer and Abinash Mohanty wrote.

The financial gains reaped by America’s least well-off families has been cited repeatedly by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell for the central bank’s willingness to keep interest rates low. The Fed cut rates in July and is poised to do so again next week, largely because of low inflation and worries about collateral damage from the U.S. trade war with China.

““People who live and work in low- and middle-income communities tell us that this job market is the best anyone can recall,” Powell said in a speech last month in Jackson, Wyo.

“Our challenge now is to do what monetary policy can do to sustain the expansion so that the benefits of the strong jobs market extend to more of those still left behind.”
